intro: Lasiospora ispahanica, commonly known as the Persian lichen, is a species of lichen that belongs to the family Parmeliaceae. It is characterized by its crustose thallus, which adheres tightly to the substrate, typically found on tree bark or rock surfaces. The plant forms a symbiotic relationship between a fungus and a green alga or cyanobacterium, which provides it with nutrients through photosynthesis. Its morphology includes a leathery, dark-colored cortex with a central, lighter-colored medulla. Lasiospora ispahanica is often found in temperate and subtropical regions, thriving in humid environments with moderate light exposure.
